description: The PDF/UA version and conformance level of a file shall be specified using the PDF/UA Identification extension schema
message: The document metadata stream doesn't contain PDF/UA Identification Schema
user_friendly_message: This PDF is missing a special label that tells assistive technologies (like screen readers) that it's designed to be accessible. Without this identification, accessibility tools may not know to treat the document as accessible, which could result in a poor experience for people with disabilities who rely on these features.
user_friendly_fix: Add `pdf-engine-opt: ["--pdf-a"]` or similar accessibility-related options to your Quarto YAML front matter to enable PDF/UA compliance metadata. The exact option name may vary by PDF engine (LaTeX vs Typst), so check your engine's documentation for the correct flag to enable PDF/UA or PDF/A standards. If your PDF engine doesn't automatically include this metadata, you may need to configure additional accessibility settings in the PDF engine's configuration files.

description: The value of "pdfuaid:part" shall be the part number of the International Standard to which the file conforms
message: The "part" property of the PDF/UA Identification Schema is %1 instead of 1 for PDF/UA-1 conforming file
user_friendly_message: This PDF claims to follow an unrecognized version of the accessibility standard. It should be marked as following PDF/UA-1 (the current standard), but it's labeled with a different version number, which means accessibility tools may not be able to properly interpret and present the document's content to users with disabilities.
user_friendly_fix: This issue indicates that the PDF/UA version metadata is set incorrectly in your document. In your Quarto YAML front matter, ensure you're specifying PDF/UA-1 compliance (not a different version) in your accessibility or PDF engine options. This may require adjusting PDF engine-specific configuration settings to explicitly request PDF/UA-1 conformance rather than other PDF standard versions.

description: Property "part" of the PDF/UA Identification Schema shall have namespace prefix "pdfuaid"
message: Property "part" of the PDF/UA Identification Schema has invalid namespace prefix %1
user_friendly_message: The accessibility label in this PDF uses the wrong formatting code, making it unreadable to assistive technologies. This is like writing an address with the wrong format—the information might be there, but systems can't find or use it properly to help people with disabilities access the content.
user_friendly_fix: This is an internal metadata formatting error that occurs during PDF generation and cannot be fixed directly in your Quarto source file or YAML configuration. You'll need to configure the PDF engine's accessibility settings to ensure it uses the correct namespace prefix format for PDF/UA metadata, which may require updating your PDF engine version or adjusting engine-specific accessibility configuration files.

description: Property "amd" of the PDF/UA Identification Schema shall have namespace prefix "pdfuaid"
message: Property "amd" of the PDF/UA Identification Schema has invalid namespace prefix %1
user_friendly_message: The accessibility amendment information in this PDF is labeled incorrectly, preventing assistive technologies from understanding which version of the accessibility standard the document follows. This formatting error means accessibility tools may not apply the correct rules when helping users with disabilities navigate the content.
user_friendly_fix: This is an internal metadata formatting error that occurs during PDF generation and cannot be fixed directly in your Quarto source file or YAML configuration. You'll need to configure the PDF engine's accessibility settings to ensure it uses the correct namespace prefix format for PDF/UA amendment metadata, which may require updating your PDF engine version or adjusting engine-specific accessibility configuration files.

description: Property "corr" of the PDF/UA Identification Schema shall have namespace prefix "pdfuaid"
message: Property "corr" of the PDF/UA Identification Schema has invalid namespace prefix %1
user_friendly_message: The accessibility correction information in this PDF is formatted incorrectly, which prevents assistive technologies from properly identifying the specific accessibility standard version being used. This mislabeling could cause accessibility tools to misinterpret how to best present the document to users with disabilities.
user_friendly_fix: This is an internal metadata formatting error that occurs during PDF generation and cannot be fixed directly in your Quarto source file or YAML configuration. You'll need to configure the PDF engine's accessibility settings to ensure it uses the correct namespace prefix format for PDF/UA correction metadata, which may require updating your PDF engine version or adjusting engine-specific accessibility configuration files.

description: The file header shall consist of "%PDF-1.n" followed by a single EOL marker, where 'n' is a single digit number between 0 (30h) and 7 (37h)
message: File header %1 does not match the pattern %PDF-1.n, where 'n' is a single digit number between 0 and 7
user_friendly_message: This file's opening identifier is improperly formatted or uses an unsupported PDF version. Like a book with a damaged cover, assistive technologies may not recognize this as a valid PDF document, preventing users with disabilities from accessing any of its content.
user_friendly_fix: This is a low-level PDF file format error that occurs during PDF generation and cannot be fixed in your Quarto source file or YAML configuration. The issue likely indicates a problem with your PDF engine installation or version—try updating your PDF engine to the latest version, or if the problem persists, switch to a different PDF engine (LaTeX or Typst) in your Quarto configuration.

description: The document catalog dictionary shall include a MarkInfo dictionary containing an entry, Marked, whose value shall be true
message: MarkInfo dictionary is not present in the document catalog, or Marked entry is set to false or is not present in the MarkInfo dictionary (MarkInfo = %1, Marked = %2)
user_friendly_message: This PDF is missing essential markers that tell assistive technologies how the content is structured (like headings, paragraphs, and lists). Without these markers, screen readers and other accessibility tools can't properly navigate or read the document aloud, making it extremely difficult for people with visual impairments to use.
user_friendly_fix: Add `pdf-engine-opt` settings to your Quarto YAML front matter to enable tagged PDF output, which creates the structural markers needed for accessibility. The specific option varies by engine—for LaTeX-based engines, this typically involves enabling tagged PDF mode, while Typst may require accessibility flags. If Quarto doesn't provide a direct option, you may need to add engine-specific configuration to enable PDF tagging in your PDF engine's settings.

description: Content marked as Artifact should not be present inside tagged content
message: Content marked as Artifact is present inside tagged content (parent struct element %1)
user_friendly_message: This PDF has decorative elements (like background images or design flourishes) incorrectly mixed in with the actual content structure. This confuses screen readers, which may announce these decorative items as if they were important content, creating a cluttered and confusing experience for users with visual impairments.
user_friendly_fix: Review your document for decorative elements (images, borders, watermarks, or design elements) that are embedded within content blocks like paragraphs or headings. Move these decorative elements outside of the main content structure, or if they're added through custom templates or includes, ensure they're placed in document margins or headers/footers rather than inline with text. If decorative elements are essential to your layout, they may need to be configured differently in your PDF engine's template settings.

description: Tagged content should not be present inside content marked as Artifact
message: Tagged content (parent struct element %1) is present inside content marked as Artifact
user_friendly_message: This PDF has important content incorrectly labeled as decorative background elements. Screen readers will skip over this content entirely, meaning users with visual impairments won't hear or access information that should be available to them.
user_friendly_fix: Review your document for content that should be accessible but may be placed in page headers, footers, or margin areas where it's being treated as decorative. Move any meaningful text, images with information, or navigational elements into the main document body. If you're using custom templates or page decoration features, ensure that actual content isn't included in those decorative sections.

description: Content shall be marked as Artifact or tagged as real content
message: Content is neither marked as Artifact nor tagged as real content
user_friendly_message: This PDF contains content that isn't labeled as either meaningful information or decorative background. Without proper labeling, assistive technologies can't determine whether to present this content to users with disabilities, potentially causing them to miss important information or hear confusing, out-of-context fragments.
user_friendly_fix: Ensure all content in your Quarto document is either part of the standard document structure (headings, paragraphs, lists, images, tables) or explicitly marked as decorative. Avoid using raw PDF commands or low-level formatting that bypasses Quarto's content structure. If you have custom content blocks or advanced layouts, this issue may require configuring your PDF engine to properly tag all document elements.

description: Files shall have a Suspects value of false(ISO 32000-1:2008, Table 321)
message: Suspects entry has a value of true
user_friendly_message: This PDF is flagged as having potentially incomplete or incorrect accessibility tagging. This warning indicates the document may have been modified after its accessibility features were created, meaning assistive technologies might encounter unexpected errors or missing information when trying to help users with disabilities access the content.
user_friendly_fix: This flag is automatically set by the PDF engine and indicates potential tagging issues in your document. Review your source document for complex formatting, custom layouts, or elements that may not be fully supported by your PDF engine's accessibility features. Regenerate the PDF from a clean Quarto render without any post-processing or manual PDF editing to ensure the accessibility structure remains intact and complete.

description: All non-standard structure types shall be mapped to the nearest functionally equivalent standard type, as defined in ISO 32000-1:2008, 14.8.4, in the role map dictionary of the structure tree root. This mapping may be indirect; within the role map a non-standard type can map directly to another non-standard type, but eventually the mapping shall terminate at a standard type
message: Non-standard structure type %1 is not mapped to a standard type
user_friendly_message: This PDF uses a custom label for organizing content that hasn't been connected to a standard type that assistive technologies understand. Without this connection, screen readers won't know how to interpret or announce this element, leaving users with disabilities unable to understand its purpose or navigate it properly.
user_friendly_fix: Avoid using custom divs, classes, or formatting structures that don't map to standard HTML/Markdown elements in your Quarto document. Stick to standard Quarto syntax for headings, paragraphs, lists, tables, figures, and code blocks. If you're using custom divs or fenced divs with special classes, replace them with standard semantic elements or ensure your PDF engine's configuration maps these custom types to standard structure types.

description: A circular mapping shall not exist
message: A circular mapping exists for %1 structure type
user_friendly_message: This PDF has a structural labeling error where a content type points back to itself in an endless loop. This circular reference will prevent assistive technologies from understanding what type of content this is, causing them to fail or behave unpredictably when users with disabilities try to access this part of the document.
user_friendly_fix: This is a structural mapping error in the PDF's internal organization that typically indicates a bug in your PDF engine's accessibility implementation. Review your document for any custom structure definitions or role mappings you may have configured, and remove them to use only standard Quarto elements. If you haven't added custom configurations, try updating your PDF engine to the latest version or switching to a different PDF engine.

description: Standard tags defined in ISO 32000-1:2008, 14.8.4, shall not be remapped
message: Standard type %1 is remapped
user_friendly_message: This PDF has incorrectly redefined a standard content label that assistive technologies rely on. By changing what a standard label means, screen readers and other accessibility tools will misinterpret the content's structure, potentially announcing headings as paragraphs or lists as tables, creating confusion for users with disabilities.
user_friendly_fix: Remove any custom role mappings or structure type redefinitions from your PDF engine configuration files. Do not attempt to redefine how standard elements (like headings, paragraphs, lists, or tables) are tagged in the PDF output. If you've modified template files or configuration settings that map standard Quarto elements to different PDF structure types, revert these changes to use the default mappings.

description: The Catalog dictionary of a conforming file shall contain the Metadata key whose value is a metadata stream as defined in ISO 32000-1:2008, 14.3.2. The metadata stream dictionary shall contain entry Type with value /Metadata and entry Subtype with value /XML
message: The document catalog dictionary doesn't contain metadata key or metadata stream dictionary does not contain either entry Type with value /Metadata or entry Subtype with value /XML
user_friendly_message: This PDF is missing essential information about the document itself (like title, author, and accessibility features) or this information isn't stored in the correct format. Without proper metadata, assistive technologies can't provide users with disabilities important context about the document before they begin reading it.
user_friendly_fix: Add document metadata to your Quarto YAML front matter including `title`, `author`, `date`, and `lang` fields. Ensure your PDF engine is configured to embed this metadata in XMP format by enabling metadata options in your YAML (this may require accessibility-related PDF engine settings). If metadata still doesn't appear correctly, you may need to update your PDF engine version or adjust engine-specific metadata configuration.

description: The Metadata stream in the document's catalog dictionary shall contain a dc:title entry, where dc is the recommended prefix for the Dublin Core metadata schema as defined in the XMP specification, which clearly identifies the document
message: Metadata stream does not contain dc:title
user_friendly_message: This PDF is missing a document title in its metadata. Without a title, assistive technologies can't announce what document users are opening, forcing people with visual impairments to guess the content or rely solely on the filename, which may not be descriptive or meaningful.
user_friendly_fix: Add a `title` field to your Quarto YAML front matter at the top of your .qmd file (e.g., `title: "Your Document Title"`). Ensure your PDF engine settings include metadata embedding—this should happen automatically in most Quarto configurations, but if the title still doesn't appear in the PDF metadata, verify that accessibility or metadata options are enabled in your PDF format settings.

description: The document catalog dictionary shall include a ViewerPreferences dictionary containing a DisplayDocTitle key, whose value shall be true
message: ViewerPreferences dictionary is not present in the document Catalog, or DisplayDocTitle key is set to false or is not present in the ViewerPreferences dictionary (ViewerPreferences = %1, DisplayDocTitle = %2)
user_friendly_message: This PDF isn't configured to display its title in the window or tab bar, showing the filename instead. This makes it harder for users with disabilities to identify and switch between open documents, especially when using screen readers that announce window titles for navigation.
user_friendly_fix: This setting controls how PDF viewers display the document and requires PDF engine configuration to set the DisplayDocTitle viewer preference to true. While you should ensure your document has a `title` in the YAML front matter, enabling this viewer preference typically requires additional PDF engine-specific settings that tell the PDF to prefer showing the title over the filename in viewer applications.

description: The logical structure of the conforming file shall be described by a structure hierarchy rooted in the StructTreeRoot entry of the document catalog dictionary, as described in ISO 32000-1:2008, 14.7
message: StructTreeRoot entry is not present in the document catalog
user_friendly_message: This PDF is missing the organizational framework that defines how its content is structured (like headings, paragraphs, lists, and tables). Without this structure, screen readers can only read the document as unorganized text in visual order, making it nearly impossible for users with visual impairments to navigate or understand the content properly.
user_friendly_fix: Enable tagged PDF output in your Quarto configuration by adding PDF engine options that create a structured document tree. This typically involves setting accessibility or tagging flags in your YAML front matter's `pdf-engine-opt` or format-specific options. If Quarto doesn't provide a direct option for your PDF engine, you'll need to configure the PDF engine's settings to enable full document tagging and structure tree generation.

description: A structure element dictionary shall contain the P (parent) entry according to ISO 32000-1:2008, 14.7.2, Table 355
message: A structure element dictionary does not contain the P (parent) entry
user_friendly_message: This PDF has a structural element that doesn't specify what it belongs to in the document hierarchy. Without this parent relationship, assistive technologies can't understand how this content fits into the overall structure, potentially causing navigation errors or skipping content when users with disabilities try to move through the document.
user_friendly_fix: This is an internal structure tree error generated during PDF creation that indicates incomplete tagging by your PDF engine. Ensure all content in your Quarto document uses proper semantic structure (headings, paragraphs, lists, etc.) without orphaned elements or improperly nested content. If your document structure is correct, this may indicate a bug in your PDF engine's tagging implementation that requires updating the engine or adjusting its accessibility configuration settings.

description: Natural language in the Outline entries shall be determined
message: Natural language in the Outline entries cannot be determined
user_friendly_message: The bookmarks in this PDF don't specify what language they're written in. Without language information, screen readers may pronounce the bookmark text incorrectly or use the wrong pronunciation rules, making navigation confusing or unintelligible for users with visual impairments.
user_friendly_fix: Add a `lang` field to your Quarto YAML front matter specifying the document language (e.g., `lang: en` for English, `lang: es` for Spanish). This setting should propagate to all document elements including bookmarks, ensuring screen readers use the correct pronunciation rules throughout the PDF including the table of contents and navigation elements.

description: Table element may contain only TR, THead, TBody, TFoot and Caption elements
test: kidsStandardTypes.split('&').filter(elem => elem != 'TR' && elem != 'THead' && elem != 'TBody' && elem != 'TFoot' && elem != 'Caption').length == 0 || kidsStandardTypes == ''
message: Table element contains %1 element(s) instead of TR, THead, TBode, TFoot or Caption
user_friendly_message: This table contains elements that don't belong in a properly structured table. Screen readers expect tables to only have rows, headers, body sections, footers, and captions—anything else will confuse the assistive technology, making it difficult or impossible for users with disabilities to understand the table's data and organization.
user_friendly_fix: Review your table markup to ensure it only contains proper table elements—rows with cells, and optionally a caption. Remove any paragraphs, images, lists, or other non-table content that's embedded directly inside the table structure. If you need to include additional content with your table, place it outside the table (before or after) rather than mixing it within the table markup.

description: TR element should be contained in Table, THead, TBody or TFoot element
message: TR element contained in %1 instead of Table, THead, TBody or TFoot element
user_friendly_message: A table row is placed outside of its proper table container. This is like having a row of data floating without being part of an actual table, which confuses screen readers and prevents them from announcing the row's relationship to other data, making the information incomprehensible to users with visual impairments.
user_friendly_fix: Ensure all table rows in your Quarto document are properly contained within a complete table structure using standard Markdown or HTML table syntax. Check that you haven't accidentally placed table row markup outside of the table delimiters or broken the table structure with improper nesting. If using complex tables, verify that all rows are fully enclosed within the table boundaries.

description: THead element should be contained in Table element
message: THead element contained in %1 instead of Table element
user_friendly_message: The table header section is placed outside of its table. Without the header being properly nested within the table structure, screen readers can't identify which rows contain column headings, making it extremely difficult for users with disabilities to understand what each column of data represents.
user_friendly_fix: Ensure your table header row is properly placed at the beginning of your table structure using standard Markdown table syntax with a header separator line (the line with dashes). Verify that nothing separates the header row from the rest of the table, and avoid using custom formatting that might break the table header from its parent table container.

description: TBody element should be contained in Table element
message: TBody element contained in %1 instead of Table element
user_friendly_message: The table body section is placed outside of its table. This structural error prevents screen readers from recognizing this as part of a table, so users with disabilities won't be able to navigate the data properly or understand its relationship to table headers and other rows.
user_friendly_fix: Ensure all data rows in your table are properly contained within the complete table structure using standard Markdown or HTML table syntax. Check that you haven't accidentally broken the table into multiple sections or placed table body content outside the table boundaries—all rows below the header should be part of one continuous table structure.

description: TFoot element should be contained in Table element
message: TFoot element contained in %1 instead of Table element
user_friendly_message: The table footer section is placed outside of its table. Without proper nesting, screen readers can't identify this as the table's footer information (like totals or summaries), preventing users with disabilities from understanding the complete context and structure of the table data.
user_friendly_fix: If you have table footer rows (like totals or summaries), ensure they're included within the same table structure as the rest of your table content. Standard Markdown tables don't directly support footers, so if you need footer functionality, either include those rows as regular data rows within the table or use HTML table syntax that properly nests the footer section within the table element.

description: TH element should be contained in TR element
message: TH element contained in %1 instead of TR element
user_friendly_message: A table header cell is placed outside of a table row. This breaks the table structure, preventing screen readers from properly associating the header with its data and announcing row/column positions, making it impossible for users with disabilities to navigate and understand the table's organization.
user_friendly_fix: Review your table to ensure all header cells are properly placed within table rows using standard Markdown table syntax. In Markdown tables, the header row is automatically created from the first row followed by the separator line with dashes—make sure you haven't accidentally placed header content outside of this structure or broken the row formatting.

description: TD element should be contained in TR element
message: TD element contained in %1 instead of TR element
user_friendly_message: A table data cell is placed outside of a table row. Without being properly contained in a row, screen readers can't announce which row and column the data belongs to, leaving users with disabilities unable to understand the data's position or relationship to headers and other cells.
user_friendly_fix: Review your table to ensure all data cells are properly placed within table rows using correct Markdown table syntax. Check that each row has the proper number of pipe separators (|) and that no cells are accidentally placed outside the table structure—every cell should be delimited by pipes and contained within a complete row.

description: TR element may contain only TH and TD elements
message: TR element contains %1 element(s) instead of TH or TD
user_friendly_message: This table row contains elements other than header or data cells. Screen readers expect rows to only contain cells—anything else disrupts the table structure, preventing users with disabilities from navigating between cells or understanding which content belongs in the table versus outside it.
user_friendly_fix: Ensure each table row contains only table cells (data or headers), not other elements like paragraphs, images, or lists embedded directly in the row. If you need to include complex content with your table, place it in separate paragraphs outside the table structure, or if the content must be in the table, put it inside the table cells themselves rather than between or alongside cells.

description: Table element should contain zero or one THead kid
message: Table element contains more than one THead kid
user_friendly_message: This table has multiple header sections when it should have only one. Having more than one header confuses screen readers about which row contains the actual column headings, making it difficult for users with disabilities to understand what each column represents or navigate the table correctly.
user_friendly_fix: Review your table to ensure it has only one header row at the top. In Markdown tables, use only one header separator line (the line with dashes), which defines a single header section. If you need multiple descriptive rows at the top, either combine them into one header row or move the additional rows into the table body as regular data rows.

description: Table element should contain zero or one TFoot kid
message: Table element contains more than one TFoot kid
user_friendly_message: This table has multiple footer sections when it should have only one. Multiple footers confuse screen readers about where the table ends and which information represents summary or total data, making it unclear for users with disabilities to understand the table's complete structure.
user_friendly_fix: If you're using HTML table syntax with footer elements, consolidate multiple footer sections into a single footer at the end of your table. Standard Markdown tables don't support footers, so if you need footer rows (like totals), include them as the last rows within the regular table body, or switch to HTML table syntax with only one properly defined footer section.

description: If Table element contains TFoot kid, Table element should contain one or more TBody kids
message: Table element contains TFoot kid, but does not contain TBody kids
user_friendly_message: This table has a footer section but no body section containing the actual data rows. This illogical structure—like having a summary without any data to summarize—will confuse screen readers and prevent users with disabilities from understanding the table's organization and content.
user_friendly_fix: Ensure your table contains actual data rows between the header and footer sections. If you're using HTML table syntax with a footer element, make sure you have data rows in the table body section. If using standard Markdown tables, avoid creating tables with only headers and footers—include at least one row of actual data content.

description: If Table element contains THead kid, Table element should contain one or more TBody kids
message: Table element contains THead kid, but does not contain TBody kids
user_friendly_message: This table has a header section but no body section containing the actual data rows. This incomplete structure—like having column headings with no data beneath them—will confuse screen readers and prevent users with disabilities from accessing the table's content or understanding its purpose.
user_friendly_fix: Ensure your table contains at least one data row below the header row. In Markdown tables, add data rows after the header separator line (the line with dashes). Every table with column headers should have corresponding data—if you don't have data to display, consider removing the table entirely or replacing it with a different content structure.

description: A table cell shall not have intersection with other cells
message: Table cell has intersection with other cells
user_friendly_message: Table cells in this PDF overlap with each other. This causes screen readers to become confused about which content belongs to which cell and where one cell ends and another begins, making the table data incomprehensible to users with disabilities.
user_friendly_fix: Review your table structure to ensure you're using proper Markdown or HTML table syntax with correct cell alignment. Check for merged cells, colspan/rowspan attributes, or complex table layouts that may be creating overlapping cells. If you need merged cells, verify that the spanning is correctly specified—otherwise, simplify your table to use a standard grid layout where each cell occupies exactly one row and column position.

description: Table element may contain a Caption element as its first or last kid
message: Table element contains Caption as its %1 child instead of first or last one
user_friendly_message: This table's caption is positioned incorrectly in the middle of the table structure instead of at the beginning or end. This improper placement confuses screen readers about when to announce the caption, potentially interrupting the flow of table data and making it harder for users with disabilities to understand what the table represents.
user_friendly_fix: Move your table caption to either immediately before or immediately after the table using Quarto's caption syntax (e.g., `: Caption text` on the line following the table). Ensure nothing is placed between the caption and the table—the caption should be the first element users encounter or the last, not embedded within the table rows themselves.

description: LI element should be contained in L element
message: LI element contained in %1 instead of L element
user_friendly_message: A list item is placed outside of an actual list structure. Without being properly contained in a list, screen readers can't identify this as part of a list or announce how many items the list contains, preventing users with disabilities from understanding the content's organization and context.
user_friendly_fix: Ensure all list items are properly contained within a list structure using standard Markdown list syntax (lines starting with `-`, `*`, `+` for unordered lists or `1.`, `2.`, etc. for ordered lists). Check that list items aren't accidentally separated from their parent list by blank lines or other content that breaks the list structure—all items should be consecutive with proper indentation.

description: LBody element should be contained in LI element
message: LBody element contained in %1 instead of LI element
user_friendly_message: The content of a list item is placed outside of the list item structure. This breaks the connection between the bullet or number and its associated text, preventing screen readers from properly announcing list items and making the list structure incomprehensible to users with disabilities.
user_friendly_fix: Review your list formatting to ensure all list item content is properly placed on the same line or correctly indented beneath the list marker (bullet or number). In Markdown, the text should immediately follow the list marker on the same line, or if you have multi-line content within a list item, indent continuation lines to maintain the list item structure without breaking it.

description: L element may contain only L, LI and Caption elements
message: L element contains %1 element(s) instead of L, LI or Caption
user_friendly_message: This list contains elements that don't belong in a properly structured list. Screen readers expect lists to only contain list items, nested lists, or captions—anything else disrupts the list structure, making it difficult for users with disabilities to navigate and understand where the list begins and ends.
user_friendly_fix: Ensure your list only contains list items and nested sublists using proper Markdown syntax—don't embed paragraphs, headings, tables, or other non-list elements directly within the list structure. If you need to include additional content with your list, place it outside the list (before or after) or, if it truly belongs with a list item, indent it properly as part of that item's content.

description: LI element may contain only Lbl and LBody elements
message: LI element contains %1 element(s) instead of Lbl or LBody
user_friendly_message: This list item contains elements other than its label (bullet or number) and body text. Screen readers expect a simple structure of marker and content—anything else confuses the assistive technology, preventing users with disabilities from understanding which text belongs to which list item.
user_friendly_fix: Use standard Markdown list syntax where each list item consists of a marker (-, *, +, or number) followed by the item's text content. Avoid inserting complex structures or non-standard formatting within individual list items—keep each item as simple text, or if you need formatted content within an item, ensure it's properly indented as part of that item's body rather than as separate elements.

description: Natural language for text in ActualText attribute shall be determined
test: ActualText == null || containsLang == true || parentLang != null || gContainsCatalogLang == true
message: Natural language for text in ActualText attribute cannot be determined
user_friendly_message: The replacement text provided for an element doesn't specify what language it's written in. Without language information, screen readers may pronounce this text incorrectly using the wrong language rules, making the content confusing or unintelligible for users with visual impairments.
user_friendly_fix: Add a `lang` field to your Quarto YAML front matter to set the document's primary language (e.g., `lang: en`). If you have ActualText attributes being generated from alt text or custom elements in different languages than the main document, you may need to use language-specific spans or divs in your source content to properly mark language changes for accessibility.

description: Natural language for text in Alt attribute shall be determined
test: Alt == null || containsLang == true || parentLang != null || gContainsCatalogLang == true
message: Natural language for text in Alt attribute cannot be determined
user_friendly_message: The alternative text describing an image or element doesn't specify what language it's written in. Without language information, screen readers may pronounce the description incorrectly, making it difficult or impossible for users with visual impairments to understand what the image or element represents.
user_friendly_fix: Add a `lang` field to your Quarto YAML front matter to set the document's primary language (e.g., `lang: en`). This language setting should apply to all alt text in your document. If you have images with alt text in a different language than the main document, wrap those images in a div or span with a language attribute to specify the alternative language for that specific content.

description: Natural language for text in E attribute shall be determined
test: E == null || containsLang == true || parentLang != null || gContainsCatalogLang == true
message: Natural language for text in E attribute cannot be determined
user_friendly_message: The expanded text for an abbreviation or acronym doesn't specify what language it's written in. Without language information, screen readers may mispronounce the full form when explaining what the abbreviation means, confusing users with visual impairments.
user_friendly_fix: Add a `lang` field to your Quarto YAML front matter to set the document's primary language (e.g., `lang: en`). This language setting should apply to all abbreviation expansions. If you have abbreviations with expansions in a different language than the main document, wrap those abbreviations in a span with a language attribute to specify the alternative language for that specific content.

description: Natural language in the Contents entry for annotations shall be determined
test: Contents == null || containsLang == true || gContainsCatalogLang == true
message: Natural language in the Contents entry for annotations cannot be determined
user_friendly_message: The text content of an annotation (like a comment or note) doesn't specify what language it's written in. user_friendly_fix: Quarto does not natively create interactive PDF forms with Form elements and widgets. If form structures are present, they were added through custom code or extensions that are creating improper form element structure. Remove any custom form generation functionality from your workflow—if you need users to fill out forms, create web-based HTML forms instead of PDF forms for proper accessibility.

description: Links shall be tagged according to ISO 32000-1:2008, 14.8.4.4.2, Link Element
message: A Link annotation is an Artifact or is nested within %1 tag (standard type = %2) instead of Link
user_friendly_message: A hyperlink is incorrectly labeled as decorative or placed in the wrong structural container. This misplacement prevents screen readers from identifying it as a clickable link, making it impossible for users with disabilities to navigate to the linked content or even know that a link exists.
user_friendly_fix: Ensure all links in your document use standard Markdown link syntax (`[link text](URL)`) rather than creating links through custom HTML, raw PDF commands, or other non-standard methods. Review any custom templates, filters, or extensions you're using to verify they don't place links in decorative sections or improper structural containers—links should always be part of the main content structure, not treated as artifacts.

description: Links shall contain an alternate description via their Contents key as described in ISO 32000-1:2008, 14.9.3
message: A link annotation does not include an alternate description in the Contents key
user_friendly_message: This hyperlink is missing descriptive text explaining where it leads. Without a description, screen readers can only announce that a link exists but can't tell users with disabilities what will happen when they click it, making navigation confusing and potentially frustrating.
user_friendly_fix: Ensure all links use descriptive link text rather than generic phrases like "click here" or bare URLs. Use Markdown link syntax with meaningful descriptions: `[descriptive text explaining destination](URL)`. The link text itself should clearly indicate where the link goes or what action it performs, so screen reader users understand the link's purpose before activating it.

description: In the media clip data dictionary, the optional CT key (ISO 32000-1:2008, 13.2.4.2, Table 274) is required
message: CT key is missing from the media clip data dictionary

user_friendly_fix: Quarto does not natively support embedding media clips directly within PDF files. If you're trying to include audio or video, link to external media files instead of embedding them in the PDF. Use standard Markdown link syntax to reference media files hosted online or stored alongside your document, which will be more accessible and compatible across different PDF viewers and assistive technologies.

description: In the media clip data dictionary, the optional Alt key (ISO 32000-1:2008, 13.2.4.2, Table 274) is required
message: Alt key (value %1) is missing from the media clip data dictionary or has incorrect value
user_friendly_message: An embedded media clip (like audio or video) is missing or has an invalid alternative text description. user_friendly_fix: Quarto does not natively support embedding media clips directly within PDF files. If you need to reference audio or video content, link to external media files using standard Markdown link syntax with descriptive link text that explains what the media contains. Alternatively, provide a text description or transcript of the media content directly in your document for accessibility.

description: PrinterMark annotations, if present, shall be considered Incidental Artifacts, as if they are hidden page elements as defined in ISO 32000-1:2008, 14.8.2.2.3
message: A PrinterMark annotation is included in logical structure
user_friendly_message: A printer's mark (a technical symbol used for professional printing) is incorrectly included in the document structure as meaningful content. These marks should be hidden from assistive technologies—including them causes screen readers to announce irrelevant printing information, creating unnecessary clutter and confusion for users with disabilities.
user_friendly_fix: Printer's marks are professional printing features not typically created by standard Quarto documents. If present, they're likely added through advanced print production workflows or custom templates. Disable any crop marks, registration marks, or color bars in your PDF generation settings, or ensure these printing features are configured to be marked as artifacts rather than document content. For standard documents, these marks should not be included.

description: A conforming file shall not contain any reference XObjects

user_friendly_message: This PDF contains a reference to external content that isn't fully embedded in the document. user_friendly_fix: Ensure all images, figures, and graphics are fully embedded in your PDF rather than referenced externally. Use standard Quarto image inclusion syntax (`![](image.png)`) with image files that are accessible during PDF generation so they get embedded completely. Avoid using advanced features that create external references or linked content—all visual elements should be self-contained within the final PDF file for proper accessibility.

description: The content of Form XObjects shall be incorporated into structure elements according to ISO 32000-1:2008, 14.7.2
message: Form XObject contains MCIDs and is referenced more than once
user_friendly_message: A reusable graphic element with structure information appears multiple times in the document. user_friendly_fix: This is a low-level PDF structure issue related to how reusable graphics are handled during PDF generation. If you're reusing the same image or graphic multiple times in your document, ensure each instance is included separately using standard image syntax rather than relying on PDF engine optimizations that reuse single graphics. If the issue persists, it may indicate a PDF engine bug that requires updating the engine version or adjusting its optimization settings.

description: The font programs for all fonts used for rendering within a conforming file shall be embedded within that file, as defined in ISO 32000-1:2008, 9.9

user_friendly_message: The actual font files used in this document aren't included in the PDF. Without embedded fonts, assistive technologies may substitute different fonts that don't have the correct character information, causing text extraction errors that make the content garbled or unreadable for users with visual impairments.
user_friendly_fix: Enable font embedding in your PDF generation settings—this should be the default behavior for most PDF engines, but verify that font embedding isn't disabled in your configuration. If you're using custom fonts, ensure they're properly installed on your system and have embedding permissions. If the issue persists, try switching to standard system fonts that are known to embed correctly, or update your PDF engine to the latest version.

description: Embedded fonts shall define all glyphs referenced for rendering within the conforming file. A font referenced solely in text rendering mode 3 is not rendered and is thus exempt from the requirements that impact the visual representation of the glyphs of a font. In all cases for TrueType fonts that are to be rendered, character codes shall be able to be mapped to glyphs according to ISO 32000-1:2008, 9.6.6.4 without the use of a non-standard mapping chosen by the conforming processor
message: Not all glyphs referenced for rendering are present in the embedded font program
user_friendly_message: Some characters used in this document are missing from the embedded font. When assistive technologies try to extract text, these missing characters will appear as blanks or incorrect symbols, making portions of the content unreadable or meaningless for users with visual impairments who rely on screen readers.
user_friendly_fix: Review your document for special characters, symbols, or non-standard glyphs that may not be included in your current font. Switch to fonts that have complete character coverage for all the characters in your document, or replace special symbols with standard characters. If using non-Latin scripts or mathematical symbols, ensure you're using fonts specifically designed to support those character sets with complete glyph coverage.

This mismatch between the font's character inventory and its actual contents can prevent assistive technologies from properly extracting text, causing missing or garbled characters when screen readers try to read the content to users with visual impairments.
user_friendly_fix: This is a font metadata error that occurs during PDF generation and cannot be fixed directly in your Quarto source document. Try using different fonts by specifying standard, well-maintained fonts in your YAML front matter. If the issue persists with Type 1 fonts, switch to TrueType or OpenType fonts which may have better metadata handling, or update your PDF engine to the latest version for improved font embedding.

Try disabling font subsetting (if your PDF engine provides that option) to embed complete fonts instead of subsets, or switch to different fonts that subset more reliably. Update your PDF engine to the latest version for improved font handling, or consider using system fonts known to work well with your PDF engine.

description: For every font embedded in a conforming file and used for rendering, the glyph width information in the font dictionary and in the embedded font program shall be consistent

This mismatch can cause assistive technologies to incorrectly extract text—words may run together, spacing may disappear, or character order may be scrambled—making the content difficult or impossible to read for users with visual impairments.
user_friendly_fix: This is a font metrics inconsistency error that occurs during PDF generation and cannot be fixed directly in your Quarto source document. Try using different fonts by specifying standard, well-tested fonts in your YAML front matter. description: For all non-symbolic TrueType fonts used for rendering, the embedded TrueType font program shall contain one or several non-symbolic cmap entries such that all necessary glyph lookups can be carried out

Switch to different TrueType or OpenType fonts that have proper Unicode character mapping tables—use standard, well-established fonts by specifying them in your YAML front matter. Update your PDF engine to the latest version, or if issues persist, consider switching PDF engines for better font encoding handling.

Remove any hidden or zero-width characters from your source document, use standard visible characters only, and ensure your text editor isn't inserting special Unicode markers. Replace any specialty characters with standard alternatives, ensure you're using fonts that contain all the characters in your document, or switch to fonts with broader character coverage. Check for copy-pasted text from other sources that may contain unusual characters—retype any problematic sections using standard keyboard characters to ensure all glyphs are properly defined.
